name: Project health check
prompt:
Step 1: Run the test suite and capture results:
  - Run the project's test command (npm test, bun test, pytest, cargo test, go test, etc.)
  - Record: total tests, passed, failed, skipped, execution time

Step 2: Measure build performance:
  - Time the build command if one exists
  - Check the size of build output (dist/, build/, target/)

Step 3: Check repository metrics:
  - Repo size: du -sh .git and total project size
  - File count by type: find . -type f | grep -v node_modules | grep -v .git
  - Lines of code: count source files (cloc or wc -l)
  - Open PRs: gh pr list --json number | jq length
  - Open issues: gh issue list --json number | jq length
  - Stale PRs (>7 days no activity): gh pr list --json number,updatedAt | filter
  - CI status: gh run list --limit 5 --json conclusion

Step 4: Compare against previous health check:
  - Read .9to5/health-history.json if it exists
  - Calculate deltas: test count change, build time change, repo size change
  - Flag regressions: test count decreased, build time increased >20%, new CI failures

Step 5: Append current metrics to .9to5/health-history.json
  Commit with message "chore: update project health metrics [automated]"

Step 6: Output a dashboard to stdout:
  - Current metrics with trend arrows (↑↓→)
  - Any regressions flagged
  - If everything is stable/improving, say "Project health: all green."
system_prompt: You are a project health monitor. Track trends, not absolutes — a test suite going from 200 to 195 tests is more concerning than having 50 tests total. Focus on regressions and anomalies. Use simple ASCII for trend indicators.
